author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: Thomas Cook aircraft's emergency slide plummeted 3,000ft into a tree
text:
9 shares 7
View
comments
Passengers heard bangs and felt a commercial jet shudder when its emergency slide suddenly came loose and plummeted to the ground over southern England.
The Thomas Cook flight was carrying hundreds of holidaymakers to Egypt when the drama unfolded shortly after take-off from London Gatwick Airport.
Two passengers said they saw an object fall from the right side of the Boeing 757-300 as it prepared to land at the airport south of London after aborting its journey.
Two passengers said they saw a white object as the slide plummeted to the ground from 3,000ft
The emergency slide (pictured) was found in a tree in a churchyard in Langton Green, east of Gatwick
The twin-engine plane was carrying 239 passengers and 10 crew when the incident occurred on 31 October last year, according to a report by the Air Accidents Investigation Branch, which revealed details of the on-board drama for the first time.
The captain and co-pilot were alerted to a problem when a ‘wing slide’ advisory message went off in the cockpit as the plane travelled along the runway.
After the plane took off the crew consulted with staff on the ground and made the decision to abort the journey to Hurghada and return to Gatwick.

Share this article Share With the plane about nine tonnes above the normal landing weight, it was forced to circle for about 40 minutes to burn off fuel, although the crew did not declare an emergency.
As the plane made its descent cabin crew and passengers heard a number of bangs and felt a brief period of shuddering.
Two passengers reported seeing a 'white object' detach from the aircraft on the right side as the slide slipped out of its carrier, hit a cabin window and fell to the ground from 3,000ft, the report stated.
As the plane made its descent those on board heard a number of bangs and felt a brief period of shuddering
The report found that a crank handle on the Boeing 757 may have moved to a release position (file photo)
It was found in a tree at a churchyard in Langton Green, Kent, about 20 miles east of Gatwick.
As the plane made its final approach the autopilot seemed to be ‘struggling’ to stay level, forcing the 50-year-old captain to disengage the autopilot and take control of the aircraft.
The plane ‘experienced some uncommanded roll’ but landed safely at Gatwick, where it was shut down on a taxiway and towed to the terminal.
The report found that the right over-wing slide carrier deployed in flight, possibly as a result of the crank handle moving to the release position.
It said an undetected loose screw in the plane’s flap system may have caused vibration that allowed the crank handle to move on its own, and the crank may have been moved closer to the release position when maintenance work was carried out the night before.
Before the incident a service bulletin had been distributed to address some of the issues cited in the report, but no action had been taken on the aircraft involved.
The report made two safety recommendations related to industry standards on doors and emergency exits, and wind slide alert procedures.
In response to the report, a Thomas Cook Airlines spokesman said: 'We took this incident extremely seriously, supported the AAIB’s investigation throughout and accept its findings entirely.
'The AAIB report confirms all our maintenance and inspection activities on this aircraft were correctly carried out prior to this event and the two recommendations made by the AAIB are industry wide, demonstrating the continuous improvements for all that can come from such events.
'Immediately following the investigation we reviewed our procedures and accelerated the completion of the amendments required to be made by 2017 on our Boeing 757s.'
